And for the past several months, I have struggled to try to explain what's going on in California's divorce and custody cases where there are attorneys acting as private judges.  And I thought this would be an excellent opportunity to try to do that a little bit better.  Because you see, private judges are essentially lawyers or retired judges.  Much like these security guards, they are privately paid.  Just as these security guards are paid by Apple, they do not have jurisdiction over the man standing on the sidewalk.  And yet that doesn't prevent these security guards from attempting to breach their jurisdiction.  I caught this one security guard who's standing behind me on the camera putting on gloves as if he intended to go hands-on on the man before they called for the police.  Had we not been there, they might have done just that.  And that's what's happening in our family courts.  These lawyers are acting as judges.  They're dragging divorce cases out for decades.  They're charging families hundreds of thousands of dollars, and they're issuing orders that result in the sale of the family homes and custody of children being taken from parents.
